If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → 0 < d
name: Pell.Solution₁.d_pos_of_one_lt_x
docString: If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

For all natural numbers d and n with d ≠ 0, d divides n if and only if the prime factorizations of d and n have the same multiplicities for each prime factor.

type: ∀ {d n : ℕ}, d ≠ 0 → n ≠ 0 → (d.factorization ≤ n.factorization ↔ d ∣ n)
name: Nat.factorization_le_iff_dvd
docString: For all natural numbers d and n with d ≠ 0, d divides n if and only if the prime factorizations of d and n have the same multiplicities for each prime factor.

This theorem states that for any two non-zero natural numbers `d` and `n`, the factorization of `d` is less than or equal to the factorization of `n` if and only if `d` divides `n`. Here, the factorization of a natural number is represented by a function that maps each prime factor of the number to its multiplicity in the number. This theorem provides a connection between the divisibility of two numbers and the relationship of their prime factorizations.

type: ∀ {d n : ℕ}, d ≠ 0 → n ≠ 0 → (d.factorization ≤ n.factorization ↔ d ∣ n)
name: Nat.factorization_le_iff_dvd
docString: This theorem states that for any two non-zero natural numbers `d` and `n`, the factorization of `d` is less than or equal to the factorization of `n` if and only if `d` divides `n`. Here, the factorization of a natural number is represented by a function that maps each prime factor of the number to its multiplicity in the number. This theorem provides a connection between the divisibility of two numbers and the relationship of their prime factorizations.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  0 < x → y < 1 → ∃ n, y ^ n < x
name: exists_pow_lt_of_lt_one
docString: For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ℕ` with `y ^ n < x`.

For all integers x and k (with k != 0), k * ⌊x / k⌋ ≤ x.

name: Int.mul_ediv_self_le
docString: For all integers x and k (with k != 0), k * ⌊x / k⌋ ≤ x.

This theorem provides a condition for the valuation at a prime `p` of the rational number `(n₁ / d₁)` to be less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of the rational number `(n₂ / d₂)`. This condition is expressed in terms of divisibility by `p^n`. Specifically, the valuation at `p` of `(n₁ / d₁)` is less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of `(n₂ / d₂)` if and only if for every natural number `n`, if `p^n` divides the product `n₁ * d₂`, then `p^n` also divides the product `n₂ * d₁`. This statement assumes that `p` is a prime number and that `n₁`, `n₂`, `d₁`, `d₂` are all non-zero integers.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact p.Prime] {n₁ n₂ d₁ d₂ : ℤ},
  n₁ ≠ 0 →
    n₂ ≠ 0 →
      d₁ ≠ 0 →
        d₂ ≠ 0 →
          (padicValRat p (Rat.divInt n₁ d₁) ≤ padicValRat p (Rat.divInt n₂ d₂) ↔
            ∀ (n : ℕ), ↑p ^ n ∣ n₁ * d₂ → ↑p ^ n ∣ n₂ * d₁)
name: padicValRat.padicValRat_le_padicValRat_iff
docString: This theorem provides a condition for the valuation at a prime `p` of the rational number `(n₁ / d₁)` to be less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of the rational number `(n₂ / d₂)`. This condition is expressed in terms of divisibility by `p^n`. Specifically, the valuation at `p` of `(n₁ / d₁)` is less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of `(n₂ / d₂)` if and only if for every natural number `n`, if `p^n` divides the product `n₁ * d₂`, then `p^n` also divides the product `n₂ * d₁`. This statement assumes that `p` is a prime number and that `n₁`, `n₂`, `d₁`, `d₂` are all non-zero integers.

Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] (f : α → β) (E : Set α) (x : α),
  ∀ᶠ (δ : ℝ) in nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0),
    Set.mulIndicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f x = Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f x
name: mulIndicator_thickening_eventually_eq_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.

Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∀ (d : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (m : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, m ≡ d [MOD n]
name: Nat.frequently_modEq
docString: Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`.

For any two elements `x`, `y` such that `0 < y`, there exists a natural number `n`
such that `x ≤ n • y`.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : OrderedAddCommMonoid α] [self : Archimedean α] (x : α) {y : α}, 0 < y → ∃ n, x ≤ n • y
name: Archimedean.arch
docString:
For any two elements `x`, `y` such that `0 < y`, there exists a natural number `n`
such that `x ≤ n • y`.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

The multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the multiplicative
indicator of the set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace β] (f : α → β)
  (E : Set α),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun δ => Set.mulIndicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f) (nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0))
    (nhds (Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f))
name: tendsto_mulIndicator_thickening_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
The multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the multiplicative
indicator of the set, as δ>0 tends to zero.

If `1 < x`, then `x^k` divides `x^l` if and only if `k` is at most `l`.

type: ∀ {x k l : ℕ}, 1 < x → (x ^ k ∣ x ^ l ↔ k ≤ l)
name: Nat.pow_dvd_pow_iff_le_right
docString: If `1 < x`, then `x^k` divides `x^l` if and only if `k` is at most `l`.

For `d ∣ n`, the totient of `n/d` equals the number of values `k < n` such that `gcd n k = d`

type: ∀ {n d : ℕ}, d ∣ n → Nat.totient (n / d) = (Finset.filter (fun k => Nat.gcd n k = d) (Finset.range n)).card
name: Nat.totient_div_of_dvd
docString: For `d ∣ n`, the totient of `n/d` equals the number of values `k < n` such that `gcd n k = d`

If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.

type: ∀ {x : ℝ}, Liouville x → ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (b : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, ∃ a, x ≠ ↑a / ↑b ∧ |x - ↑a / ↑b| < 1 / ↑b ^ n
name: Liouville.frequently_exists_num
docString:
If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.

For `a ≤ b`, `a` left divides `b`

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Mul α] [inst_1 : LE α] [self : ExistsMulOfLE α] {a b : α}, a ≤ b → ∃ c, b = a * c
name: ExistsMulOfLE.exists_mul_of_le
docString: For `a ≤ b`, `a` left divides `b`

If a differentiable function `f` is approximated by a linear map `A` on a set `s`, up to `δ`,
then at almost every `x` in `s` one has `‖f' x - A‖ ≤ δ`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E] {s : Set E}
  {f : E → E} [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_4 : BorelSpace E] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure E)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddHaarMeasure μ] {A : E →L[ℝ] E} {δ : NNReal},
  ApproximatesLinearOn f A s δ →
    MeasurableSet s →
      ∀ (f' : E → E →L[ℝ] E),
        (∀ x ∈ s, HasFDerivWithinAt f (f' x) s x) → ∀ᵐ (x : E) ∂MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict μ s, ‖f' x - A‖₊ ≤ δ
name: ApproximatesLinearOn.norm_fderiv_sub_le
docString:
If a differentiable function `f` is approximated by a linear map `A` on a set `s`, up to `δ`,
then at almost every `x` in `s` one has `‖f' x - A‖ ≤ δ`.

If a fundamental solution exists, then `d` must be positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, Pell.IsFundamental a → 0 < d
name: Pell.IsFundamental.d_pos
docString: If a fundamental solution exists, then `d` must be positive.

Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `δ > 0`,
there exists `η` such that two functions bounded by `η` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `δ`. One
could take `η = δ / 2` for `p ≥ 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} (E : Type u_2) {m0 : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α) [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  (p : ENNReal) {δ : ENNReal},
  δ ≠ 0 →
    ∃ η,
      0 < η ∧
        ∀ (f g : α → E),
          MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable f μ →
            MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g μ →
              MeasureTheory.snorm f p μ ≤ η → MeasureTheory.snorm g p μ ≤ η → MeasureTheory.snorm (f + g) p μ < δ
name: MeasureTheory.exists_Lp_half
docString:
Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `δ > 0`,
there exists `η` such that two functions bounded by `η` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `δ`. One
could take `η = δ / 2` for `p ≥ 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ∣ b → Int.natAbs b < Int.natAbs a → b = 0
name: Int.eq_zero_of_dvd_of_natAbs_lt_natAbs
docString:
If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

The multiplicative indicators of closed δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the
multiplicative indicator of the set, as δ tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace β] (f : α → β)
  (E : Set α),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun δ => Set.mulIndicator (Metric.cthickening δ E) f) (nhds 0) (nhds (Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f))
name: tendsto_mulIndicator_cthickening_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
The multiplicative indicators of closed δ-thickenings of a set tend pointwise to the
multiplicative indicator of the set, as δ tends to zero.

Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x₀, r * x₀)` and if `P` for `[x₀, r^n * x₀)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x₀, r^(n+1) * x₀)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ≥ x₀`.

type:
∀ {P : ℝ → Prop} (x₀ r : ℝ),
  1 < r →
    0 < x₀ →
      (∀ x ∈ Set.Ico x₀ (r * x₀), P x) →
        (∀ n ≥ 1, (∀ z ∈ Set.Ico x₀ (r ^ n * x₀), P z) → ∀ z ∈ Set.Ico (r ^ n * x₀) (r ^ (n + 1) * x₀), P z) →
          ∀ x ≥ x₀, P x
name: Real.induction_Ico_mul
docString:
Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x₀, r * x₀)` and if `P` for `[x₀, r^n * x₀)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x₀, r^(n+1) * x₀)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ≥ x₀`.

If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a nontrivial solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ}, 0 < d → ¬IsSquare d → ∃ a, a ≠ 1 ∧ a ≠ -1
name: Pell.Solution₁.exists_nontrivial_of_not_isSquare
docString:
If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a nontrivial solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1`.

Nonnegativity of an element of `ℤ√d`.

type: {d : ℕ} → ℤ√↑d → Prop
name: Zsqrtd.Nonneg
docString: Nonnegativity of an element of `ℤ√d`.

If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1` with `x > 1` and `y > 0`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ}, 0 < d → ¬IsSquare d → ∃ a, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a ∧ 0 < Pell.Solution₁.y a
name: Pell.Solution₁.exists_pos_of_not_isSquare
docString:
If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1` with `x > 1` and `y > 0`.
